headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 02-04-01: Salient Facts: AntiSmoking Campaign; Rotten Teeth and Dead Babies

docs.abstract: Canada is requiring cigarette makers to carry on 50 percent of each pack graphic representations of health hazards of smoking; responds to research suggesting warnings accompanied by pictures are 60 times more likely to inspire smokers to quit than text-only warnings; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ARE THOSE PACKS OF DISEASED ORGANS? No, or at least not literally. Those are the new Canadian cigarette packs. American cigarette packs may have to make space for a straightforward reminder that cigarette smoking is a health hazard. But to our north, cigarette makers now have to turn over 50 percent of each pack to graphic representations of just what those hazards look like. And it's not pretty. The 16 designs include photographs of cancerous lungs, stroke-clotted brains, damaged hearts and bloody mouths in acute periodontal distress. More subtle warnings include a very pregnant woman holding a cigarette, a premature baby in a hospital and, for the fellas, a limply curling cigarette to remind them of the link between smoking, bad circulation and impotence.
